More detailed Grouping

Introduction to advanced date groupin

What about finding the difference between dates for two tests for a single patient. We use the same process, but this time the mutate column uses difftime to get the difference between the current row within a group and the previous column (using lag(). If you want the difference between the current and the next row then use lead())

Upstage<-df %>% arrange(HospNum_Id, dat) %>% group_by(HospNum_Id) %>%
  mutate(diffDate = difftime(dat, lag(dat,1),units = "days"))
kable(head(Upstage,25))
proc dat HospNum_Id diffDate
RFA 2013-07-10 D0739033 NA
EMR 2015-02-13 D0739033 583 days
EMR 2017-01-25 D0739033 712 days
Biopsies 2014-02-17 F630230 NA
EMR 2014-08-22 F630230 186 days
RFA 2014-09-15 F630230 24 days
EMR 2015-05-11 F630230 238 days
Biopsies 2015-07-11 F630230 61 days
RFA 2016-09-02 F630230 419 days
Biopsies 2013-05-15 G244224 NA
RFA 2013-05-27 G244224 12 days
EMR 2013-12-06 G244224 193 days
Biopsies 2014-11-26 G244224 355 days
RFA 2015-08-26 G244224 273 days
Biopsies 2015-11-20 G244224 86 days
Biopsies 2013-11-15 J322909 NA
EMR 2013-12-07 J322909 22 days
Biopsies 2014-03-20 J322909 103 days
EMR 2014-06-04 J322909 76 days
RFA 2015-10-04 J322909 487 days
RFA 2016-12-03 J322909 426 days
Biopsies 2017-01-15 J322909 43 days
EMR 2013-09-05 K522332 NA
EMR 2014-08-04 K522332 333 days
Biopsies 2014-10-06 K522332 63 days

What if you simply want to plot out the number of procedures done by year. That needs you to extract the year from the date and then summarise as follows:

Tots<-df %>%
  mutate(year = format(dat, "%Y")) %>%
  group_by(year)%>%
  summarise(n = n())

kable(Tots)
year n
2013 23
2014 22
2015 25
2016 25
2017 5

of course you can mix in other things into dplyr, and this could have been done using the in-built r function table()

Tots<-df %>%
  mutate(year = format(dat, "%Y"))
  mytable<-table(Tots$year)
  mytable
## 
## 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 
##   23   22   25   25    5
